content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my cautious nature and preference for predictability, I would choose R{}. The reason is that if the other player also chooses R, we both earn 45$ per round, which provides a higher return than choosing B (20$) or taking turns choosing each other's payoff (40$). Additionally, the game has 75 rounds, so even if there's a slight chance that the other player may choose B, the overall potential gain by choosing R consistently outweighs the risk of lower earnings in individual rounds.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent chose B in the previous round, I will choose R{}. In this situation, if my opponent chooses R in the next round, I will receive 45$ while they will get nothing. However, if my opponent chooses B again, I will earn 0$, and they will get 40$. But considering that I want to maximize my earnings in the long run (75 rounds), it is more beneficial for me to choose R and hope that my opponent eventually switches their choice to increase my chances of earning a higher payoff.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Given that my opponent also chose R, I will choose R{}. In this case, both of us will receive 45$ per round since we have chosen the same option. Since we are both earning the maximum possible payoff for each round when we both choose R, it is in our best interest to continue choosing R as long as my opponent also chooses R to maximize our earnings during the entire experiment (75 rounds).
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since both of us have chosen R and received a payoff of 45$ in the previous round, I will choose R{}. As long as my opponent continues to choose R, we will both earn 45$ per round during the entire experiment (75 rounds). Since this is the best possible outcome for both of us given our cautious nature and preference for predictability, it makes sense to stick with the strategy that provides a consistent payoff.
